column4: Hi there, I've been using windows/dos for 17 years, but i want to give linux a shot, can anyone help me out with a problem?
I'm trying to compile a driver for my wireless pcmcia in ubuntu
and i need to install a normal set of linux dev tools and try again
no, but i think it supports the spectrum24 (aka intel 2011)
how does that work?
yes, intel points me to some, I'm trying to compile them
hiddenwolf: invalid operation
they may already exist in the default kernel if supported
I think he meant   sudo apt-get install build-essential
no, just give you the tools
yes, it's the GNU C compiler
/usr/bin/gcc
to find an executable, type   which <name>
to read the manual, type ` man gcc`
and put aside a few days.... hehe
oh, sorry you mentioned ndiswrapper
this might all be unnecessary if the module exists and your card is supported by the kernel... do you know it isn't?
as i said, $(uname -r) expands to the correct kernel
type  uname -r to see
you normally accept defaults
that way the system knows where they are ;)
